title: Dr
name: Adam Dennis
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Machine learning, Optimisation, Safety and ethics
short_biography: Adam recently completed his PhD in the Blast and Impact Dynamics research group at the University of Sheffield. His project, titled 'Machine Learning Tools for Blast Load Prediction in Obstructed Environments', explored a range of methods for developing rapid analysis tools that can assist with human injury prediction and structural damage estimations following the detonation of a high explosive. He is now continuing this work within the group, aiming to apply Machine Learning approaches to a range of problems.
research_interest_summary:
My research and professional interests are currently centered around the development of Fast Running Engineering Models (FREMs), with a focus on applying novel Machine learning methods to improve existing analysis approaches. At present, this covers the following topics:

- Complex blast loading prediction
- Human injury prevention
- Structural response estimation
- Computational modelling
- Efficient building design

title: Dr
name: Adam Stanton
position: Lecturer in Data Science and AI
research_areas: Data-centric Engineering, Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Machine learning, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Optimisation, Robotics, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Visualisation
short_biography: I am a Lecturer in Data Science and AI in the Information School at the University of Sheffield. My last position was as a Research Software Engineer at TUoS and the Alan Turing Institute, and before that I held lectureships in Computer Science at Aston University in Birmingham and at Keele University near to Stoke-on-Trent. My research background is in bioinspired autonomous systems: I studied Artificial Intelligence and Computer Science at the University of Birmingham and gained a PhD in Evolutionary Robotics from the University of Keele.
research_interest_summary:
Bioinspired Autonomous Systems
Ethics of Data Science and AI
FATES (Fairness, Accountability, Transparency, Ethics, Safety, Security, Sustainability) in AI
Good Practice in AI Software Engineering

title: Professor
name: Ali Khurram
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Science, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Information theory, Machine learning, Speech recognition
short_biography:
I am a Professor and Hon. Consultant Pathologist. Prior to that, I worked as a Senior Clinical Lecturer (2016-2022) and as a NIHR Academic Clinical Lecturer/ Honorary Specialist Registrar (2011-2016) at the University of Sheffield. 

I have a strong interest and am actively involved in research and teaching (undergraduate, postgraduate, clinical) as well as diagnostic pathology. I am the founder and Lead of the NEOPATH Research Group which is a team of researchers and clinicians working on various aspects of head and neck cancer diagnosis and prognosis prediction. 

I work closely with a number of patient groups and charities and am a Patron for The Swallows Head and Neck Cancer Charity.
research_interest_summary: One of my main interests is the application of Artificial Intelligence and Machine/Deep Learning to Pathology and to aid early detection. At present, I am involved in a number of national and international collaborative projects exploring ‘novel digital biomarkers’ in cancers and pre-cancers.

title: Professor
name: Aline Villavicencio
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Information retrieval, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Social data science, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: I am affiliated to the  Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield (UK). I received my PhD from the University of Cambridge  (UK) in 2001, and held postdoctoral positions at the University of Cambridge  and University of Essex (UK). I have also been a Visiting Scholar at the MIT (USA) in 2014/2015 and in 2011/2012. In 2014 I was a Visiting Scholar at the Labo­ra­toire LaTTiCe at the École Normale Supé­rieure (France), in 2012/2013 an Erasmus-Mundus Visiting Scholar at Saarland University (Germany) and from 2006-2009 at the University of Bath. From 2007-2017 I had a Research Fellowship from the Brazilian Scientific Research Council (CNPq).
research_interest_summary: My research interests are in Natural Language Processing, multilinguality, and cognitively motivated models of language, for typical and clinical conditions.

title: Professor
name: Amaka C Offiah
affiliation: University of Sheffield and Sheffield Children's Hosptial
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Information retrieval, Machine learning
short_biography: I am a clinical academic with my major interest being in optimising and improving the diagnosis of child physical abuse and in differentiating abuse from underlying musculoskeletal disorders and bone fragility. I am one of only a few black female professors in the UK (as of 2023). I am Chair of the European Society of Paediatric Radiology Child Abuse Task Force and Managing Editor (outside the Americas) for the journal Pediatric Radiology, being the first female and the first person from an ethnic minority background to hold this role.
research_interest_summary: I'm interested in using AI to identify the subtle fractures seen on images obtained in suspected child abuse; in collating and identifying patterns that might improve the diagnosis of abuse from the large volume of data obtained for each child in accidental and suspected abuse scenarios and in using AI to improve our understanding of injury mechanisms in infants.

title: Ms
name: Amnah Alluqmani
position: PhD student at the information school
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Information retrieval, Knowledge representation, Social data science
short_biography: I'm a PhD student in Data Science. I work on generating visual representations of clothing images to assist people with visual impairments in purchasing online.
research_interest_summary: Knowledge representation - information retrieval computer vision

title: Dr
name: Anastasia Karpunina
research_interest_terms: Safety and ethics, Social data science
short_biography: I am an experienced social worker specialising in working with children and families at risk. After frontline practice, I transitioned into academia as a social work educator and a researcher, focusing on the intersection of AI, pedagogy, and social work.
research_interest_summary: My research explores the use of virtual environments and AI avatars in social work education. My current project examines how AI can meet the demands of professions that rely on communication and interaction with diverse and vulnerable individuals. I am also interested in the ethical challenges and biases associated with AI that may impact the learning process.

title: Dr
name: Andrew Cox
research_interest_terms: Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Social data science
research_interest_summary: My main interests are in the responsible implementation of AI systems in the context of libraries (e.g. university and national libraries, health libraries or the corporate or government context) and their impact on the information profession. So I am interested in the strategic decision making around AI, the relevant applications, ethics issues, the competencies required by professionals to support them and the implementation drivers and challenges.

title: Professor
name: Ashutosh Tiwari
affiliation: Faculty Director of Research and Innovation - Engineering, University of Sheffield
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Human computer interface, Machine learning, Optimisation, Robotics
short_biography: Professor Ashutosh Tiwari (PhD CEng FIMechE FIET) holds the prestigious RAEng/Airbus Research Chair in Digital Manufacturing at the University of Sheffield. He is also the Faculty Director of Research and Innovation for Engineering at the University of Sheffield. Internationally renowned for research in digital manufacturing, he has a track record of leading cross-TRL projects worth over £15mn, produced 343 publications (155 journal and 133 conference papers, h-index 38, citation count over 9,000), graduated 36 PhDs, and was awarded an EPSRC HVM Catapult Fellowship. He is an Associate Editor of ‘AI for Engineering Design, Analysis and Manufacturing Journal’ (Cambridge University Press).
research_interest_summary: AI for Manufacturing

title: Professor
name: Caitlin Buck
research_areas: Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: I started my career by completing a BSc in Archaeological Science (1987, Bradford) and a PhD in Statistics (1994, Nottingham). My research interests lie in the applications of Bayesian statistics to archaeology and palaeoenvironmental science. I am best known for my work to popularise the use of Bayesian statistics in radiocarbon calibration, which are widely held to have revolutionised archaeological chronology construction.
research_interest_summary:
My current interests lie in extending the use of Bayesian methods to the complete archaeological post-excavation process. In particular, my team are:
- working with experts in a range of archaeolgical find types, developing formal elicitation methods for recording date estimates using probability distributions. 
- exploring options for using graph theory along with probabilistic methds to enhance the management of chronological information during the post-excavation process.

title: Mr
name: Calum Robison
research_areas: Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Safety and ethics, Social data science
short_biography: Calum is a postgraduate law student at the University of Sheffield, specializing in patent law. With a BSc in Chemistry and experience as a research polymer chemist, he brings a multidisciplinary perspective to his legal studies. He transitioned to law after recognizing the disruptive impact of generative artificial intelligence on patent law. Currently, Calum is focusing his research on the impact of inventive generative AI on patent law's inventive step requirement. He aims to provide rational and well-founded policy suggestions that balance the need to incentivise the development and utilisation of inventive AI with the risks of awarding patents too leniently.
research_interest_summary: Calum's current research is centred on analysing the impact of inventive generative Artificial Intelligence on the inventive step requirement for patentability in the UK and EU. He is also enthusiastic to discus the broader implications of Artificial Intelligence on patent law.

title: Dr
name: Cass Zhixue Zhao
research_areas: Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Natural language processing

title: Dr
name: Charith Abhayaratne
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Security and Business and Public Policy, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Machine learning, Privacy and trust, Robotics
short_biography: Dr Abhayaratne received the B.E. (Hons) in electrical and electronic engineering from The University of Adelaide, Australia (1998), and the Ph.D. in electronic and electrical engineering from the University of Bath, U.K. (2002). He received the European Research Consortium for Informatics and Mathematics (ERCIM) Postdoctoral Fellowship (2002-2004) for research at Centre of Mathematics and Computer Science (CWI), The Netherlands and the National Research Institute for Computer Science and Control (INRIA), France. He serves as an Associate Editor for IEEE Transactions on Image Processing (2019 - ), IEEE Access (2020 - ), and Journal of Information Security and Applications (JISA) (2018 -).
research_interest_summary:
- Development of robust machine learning models and software for computer vision and visual data (image/video) analysis - with applications in human action recognition, assisted living, navigation, robotics, medical image analysis, food recognition and nutrition estimation.
- Image and video data protection, authentication and visual misnformation dtection with applications in deepfake and manipulated image detection and localisation.
- Neuromrphic vision sensing and analysis of data acaptured from neuromorphic sensors.
- Weekly supervised semantic segmentation
- Robustness and explaianability of machine learning models.

title: Dr
name: Chen Chen
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning, Optimisation, Privacy and trust
short_biography: Dr Chen (Cherise) Chen obtained her MSc and Ph.D. degree in Advanced Computing from Imperial College London, in 2016 and 2022, respectively. From 2022, she worked as a research associate at Imperial College London. During the time at Imperial, she worked closely with Prof. Daniel Rueckert and Dr. Wenjia Bai, on numerous projects with cardiac imaging. She was also a research scientist at HeartFlow. After that, she joined Oxford BioMedIA group, University of Oxford in 2023, working closely with Prof. Vicente Grau. She has engaged in a variety of projects that apply artificial intelligence to cardiac, brain, and prostate imaging.
research_interest_summary: Dr. Chen's research primarily revolves around the intersection of artificial intelligence (AI) and healthcare. Her focus is particularly strong in the domains of medical multi-modal data analysis (e.g, image, signal, text) with machine learning. Her work aims to develop and validate robust, data-efficient, and reliable machine learning algorithms that can enhance the scalability of AI-driven medical data analysis in practical applications.

title: Mr
name: Dave Holloway
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Social media, Visualisation
research_interest_summary: AI image generation. Accessibility.

title: Mr
name: David King
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Computer systems and architectures, Computer vision, Human computer interface, Machine learning, Multi-agent reasoning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Optimisation, Robotics, Safety and ethics, Visualisation
short_biography:
David has over twenty years of industrial experience in product research and development (R&D). He began his career developing industrial control and instrumentation systems. This was followed by seventeen years working in R&D for a global OEM developing award winning industrial products for infrared non-contact temperature measurement and thermal imaging. David's engineering qualifications include Electronics and Control Systems Engineering and Computer Science. David is also a PhD researcher within the UoS EEE researching the application of Hyperspectral Imaging and Machine Learning.
David is also a Co-director of the UoS INSIGNEO Institute smart devices and sensors theme.
research_interest_summary: David's current research interests include Digital Healthcare, I4.0 sensor systems, machine learning, AI in design, and digital technology to enable the circular economy.

title: Professor
name: Davide Costanzo
research_interest_terms: Computer systems and architectures, Data structures and algorithms, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Parallel computing
short_biography:
I am the head of the particle physics group, where we focus on fundamental science and research on elementary particles and their role in the Universe structure. Particle physics has vast datasets to process and large international collaborations devoted to this work. 

In 2018-20, before Covid, I worked at CERN as the leader of the ATLAS computing project, leading a team of 100 developers and computing experts, using 300k core processors and hosting 200 PBytes of data worldwide.

I am currently the PI of the UK SWIFT-HEP project (Software infrastructure for high energy physics) and the related ExCALIBUR working group, joining 8 institutes across the UK.
research_interest_summary:
My personal research interest is in the search for supersymmetry and the physics that would explain the nature of Dark Matter. There is 5 times more dark matter in the Universe than regular matter, yet, we do not know what Dark Matter is made of.

We search for the elusive Dark Matter particles as they may be produced at CERN in proton-proton collisions (ATLAS experiments, 3000 collaborators). We also search for Dark Matter as it interacts with highly sensitive detectors, such as in the proposed £300M XLZD experiment to be hosted at the STFC Boulby Laboratory in Yorkshire.

In particle physics, we collect sets of data (EBytes) and I am interested in the simulation of these experiments, and the data curation, management and processing.

title: Dr
name: Denis Newman-Griffis
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Safety and ethics, Social data science
short_biography: I am a Lecturer in Data Science in the University of Sheffield's Information School and Deputy Coordinator of the MSc in Data Science. I was an NLM Postdoctoral Fellow in the University of Pittsburgh Department of Biomedical Informatics, a Pre-Doctoral Fellow of the National Institutes of Health Clinical Center, and did my PhD at the Ohio State University. I have conducted research across NLP, machine learning, medical informatics, and responsible and ethical AI. I received the American Medical Informatics Association (AMIA) Doctoral Dissertation Award for my work at the intersection of NLP and disability, and am a member of the UK Young Academy. I proudly identify as queer and neurodivergent, and my pronouns are they/them.
research_interest_summary:
I am interested in responsible and effective AI, in terms of principles, practices, and projects. I am currently working across several interrelated areas: (1) intersection of informatics and disability, in terms of how data science and AI methods conceive of, implement, and analyse disability; (2) responsible and effective data science, in terms of best practices grounded in social and organisational context; (3) practical natural language processing for health; and (4) applied text analysis for the science of science.

- Information extraction
- Representation learning
- Critical disability studies
- Responsible and ethical AI
- Professional practices of data science
- Translational NLP

title: Professor
name: Dennis Wang
position: Advanced Visiting Fellow, University of Sheffield
affiliation: Imperial College London and A*STAR Bioinformatics Institute
research_interest_terms: Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Privacy and trust, Visualisation
short_biography:
Prof Dennis Wang holds the Academy of Medical Sciences Professorship (Chair in Data Science) at Imperial College London, and is a Visiting Fellow at the University of Sheffield. Additionally, he is a principal investigator with both A*STAR’s Singapore Institute for Clinical 
 Sciences and the Bioinformatics Institute. He received his PhD in Biostatistics from the University of Cambridge, followed by postdoctoral research at AstraZeneca and Microsoft Research in the area of computational biology.
research_interest_summary: Dennis’ research focuses on translating patterns in the human genome into actionable information that accelerates the development of treatments for complex diseases. Specialising in big data analysis, drug development (small molecules and biologics), algorithmic development, software design, web service development, genomic profiling, and statistical inference. His experience includes applying machine learning and statistical approaches to identify patterns from large genomic data sets and providing clinically actionable biomarkers to drug development teams.

title: Dr
name: Diana Maynard
research_areas: Data-centric Engineering, Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Natural language processing, Social data science, Social media
short_biography: Dr. Diana Maynard has been working in Natural Language Processing for over 30 years. Since 2000 she has been one of the key developers of the GATE NLP toolkit, leading work on Sheffield’s open-source multilingual text analysis tools. Her main research interests are in practical, multidisciplinary approaches to text and social media analysis. She is currently working on various projects based around the detection, analysis and escalation of online hate speech, bias in Machine Learning. She has strong interests in journalist safety working closely with the Centre for Freedom of the Media and the Department of Journalism, Media and Communication; as well as in sustainability, working with the Institute for Sustainable Food.

title: Dr
name: Donghwan Shin
research_areas: Security and Business and Public Policy, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Safety and ethics
short_biography: I am a lecturer (assistant professor in the American system) at the Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield, Sheffield, UK. My research interests lie in mutation testing, testing for ML-enabled cyber-physical systems (e.g., ML-enabled automated driving systems), and log analysis (e.g., model inference and anomaly detection). I have published many research papers at venues such as ICSE, ICST, ISSTA, and MODELS and journals such as TSE, EMSE, and STVR. Please see my Google Scholar page (https://scholar.google.co.kr/citations?user=6uSW0MQAAAAJ) for details.
research_interest_summary: More and more software systems are integrated with Artificial Intelligence (AI), especially Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL). However, ML/DL models are inherently different from traditional software programs; such models obtain decision logic via "training", whereas traditional programs obtain it via "programming". To address this challenge, I developed an automated test data (image) generation technique for DL models with many outputs (e.g., DNNs for facial key-point detection). Also, I developed efficient testing techniques for ML-enabled Automated Driving Systems (ADS) using surrogate models and reinforcement learning.

title: Mr
name: Edward Rawson
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: I am a PhD student in the Department of Mechanical Engineering and have previously completed a BEng in the same department. In my free time, I enjoy running and cycling both in the Peaks and at home in the Pennines.
research_interest_summary: My research is on deep learning methods towards the control of alloy microstructures via a novel multi-laser powder bed fusion process; Diode Area Melting. Specifically, I am finding ways to incorporate prior knowledge into video Generative Adversarial Networks to increase data efficiency, interpretability and physical realism of predictions. Towards this goal, I am also interested in graph networks and implicit neural representation.

title: Mr
name: Edwin Brown
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography:
Edwin joined the Research Software Engineer (RSE) team in October 2022. He comes from a background in geophysics following a BSc and MSc in Geophysical Sciences at the University of Leeds. After university, he worked in the private sector, developing machine learning (ML) workflows to solve geophysical imaging and inversion problems.

Edwin has practical experience in the designing, training and evaluation of ML models. He is experienced in Python having worked with data science libraries such as Numpy, Pandas, Scikit-learn, Tensorflow and Keras. He has a growing interest in MLOps (Machine Learning Operations) and the practical challenges of scaling up ML practices.
research_interest_summary: Edwin's role as a Research Software Engineer (RSE) is to aid researchers in Machine Learning Projects. This can be as simple as bug fixing a training script to more complex challenges such as developing software for an end-to-end machine learning project. He also helps deliver Git and Deep Learning training.

title: Mr
name: Eytan Canzini
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Data structures and algorithms, Information theory, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Optimisation, Robotics, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: Eytan Canzini received a MEng degree in Aerospace Engineering from the University of Sheffield, and is currently undertaking a PhD in Automatic Control. His work focuses on combining control methods with machine learning in the fields of robotics and space systems. Prior to starting his PhD, Eytan spent time in industry working in a variety of roles in the semiconductor and aerospace sectors. During this time, he worked on the development of an autonomous aerospace testing rig that allowed for the certification of wing panel heating prior to flight and the use of autonomous robotics to aid semiconductor printers with aligning electronic components. He is a member of IEEE and RaeS and is a Research Scientist at Airbus Robotics.
research_interest_summary: Eytan’s research interests align the growing fields of machine learning and automatic control within the environment of practical applications to robotics. His research interests include optimisation, game theory, reinforcement learning and applied machine learning in the fields of robotics, space systems, manufacturing and multi-agent systems. He is particularly interested in using reinforcement learning as an optimisation tool to learn policy capable of performing optimally in environments where information is either limited or unreliable, and how using optimal control methods can improve the performance of robotics in both terrestrial and space settings.

title: Dr
name: Gavin Boyce
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Visualisation
short_biography: I have a background in Philosophy, Computing and Psychology. I currently work as Head of Faculty & Research Partnership in the University of Sheffield library. Day-to-day I head up the small, but perfectly formed, Faculty Engagement team; 12 dedicated specialist librarians who endeavour to support both staff and student needs across all disciplines within the University. Much of my focus is on ensuring that the Library will continue to be the beating heart of the University in five to ten years time and in the current environment this requires a combination of careful long-term planning and fleet-footed opportunism.
research_interest_summary: My PhD thesis was on the topic of Artificial Intelligence, an an interdisciplinary piece of work that had neither the a priori rigour that it takes to satisfy pure philosophers, nor sufficient lines of code to mollify decent computer scientists. I spent my nights working on Yorick Wilkes' Japanese-Electronic dictionary. I have leaned towards AI, HCI and the applications thereof ever since.

title: Professor
name: George Panoutsos
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Machine learning, Optimisation
short_biography: George Panoutsos received his PhD degree in automatic control and systems engineering from the University of Sheffield, Sheffield, U.K, in 2007. He joined the Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering (University of Sheffield, UK) as a Lecturer in 2010, and promoted to Professor of Computational Intelligence in 2019.
research_interest_summary: George has a research grant portfolio of over £3M from the UK EPSRC, Innovate UK, EU Horizon 2020 and direct industry funding, as well as over 100 research publications in theoretical as well as applied contributions in the areas of computational intelligence, data-driven modelling, optimisation, and decision support systems. In terms of applied research, the majority of his work is on advanced manufacturing systems, as well as healthcare applications, while also currently exploring research applications in infrastructure.

title: Ms
name: Ghada Sasi
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Visualisation
short_biography: I obtained my Bachelor of Science in Biology with honors (1st Prize, Merit) from Omar Al Mukhtar University in Derna, Libya, in 2007. Following that, I served as a research assistant at the same campus. I then completed my Master’s in Plant Physiology from Ain Shams University in Cairo, Egypt, in 2019. Currently, I am pursuing my PhD under Dr. Adrien Chauvet in the School of Mathematical and Physical Sciences, Department of Chemistry. Co-Supervisors Professor Stephen Rolfe, School of Biosciences, and Professor Stephen Matcher, Department of Electronic and Electrical Engineering, TUoS. My PhD focuses on using Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT), a novel laser-based imaging techniques, to detect early infection of crops.
research_interest_summary: We collaborated with a software company to develop machine learning-based software tailored to our project for OCT image segmentation and classification.

title: Dr
name: Giuliano Punzo
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Mathematical modelling, Multi-agent reasoning
short_biography: Dr Punzo received the BEng and the MEng in aerospace engineer from the University of Naples Federico II and forked for a brief period at Thales Alenia Space (Turin). He started the doctoral studies and was awarded a PhD in Swarm Engineering in 2014 at the University of Strathclyde in Glasgow. Giuliano held research and teaching posts at the University of Strathclyde, the University of Glasgow and The University of Sheffield before becoming a lecturer in Aerospace Systems at the department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering at the University of Sheffield in 2019.
research_interest_summary: Giuliano’s research interests are in the broad area of control theory and complex systems. His current research aims at understanding complex dynamics at the interface between social and technical systems. These include the use of public services such as transportation or water systems, how these impact the demographic and the resilience of both the infrastructure and the community they serve. Research areas of interest include network theory, control theory, games on networks, consensus, and complexity.

title: Dr
name: Grant Hill
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Optimisation, Visualisation
short_biography: I obtained my MChem degree from the University of York in 2002, followed by a PhD in theoretical chemistry from the same institute in 2005. After periods of postdoctoral study in Cardiff and Washington State, I had a temporary position at the University of Glasgow. I joined the University of Sheffield in 2014.
research_interest_summary: I am interested in exploring fundamental questions in chemistry/physics at the molecular level using theoretical and computational tools. Recent areas of focus include the use of data science and machine learning techniques to design new molecules/materials and to improve the methods of quantum chemistry.

title: Dr
name: Grigorios Kyritsakas
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Optimisation, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: Dr Grigorios Kyritsakas received his MEng in Environmental Engineering from the Technical University of Crete and his Msc in hydrology from Imperial College London. He then worked as a water engineering consultant for a period of 10 years working on the design of water and wastewater treatment plants and distribution systems. He then got back in academia in 2017 to purchase a PhD in data analytics for drinking water quality at University of Sheffield Civil and Structural engineering department. With the completion of his studies in 2021, he stayed in the department as a post-doc research associate working on machine learning application for improving drinking water quality.
research_interest_summary: Grigorio's research interests are in the are of water quality, hydraulics, water infrastructures, and public health. His current research focuses on application of machine learning applications for understanding factors related to water quality deterioration, predicting future deterioration events and improving the quality of the water that is consumed. His research area of interest also includes the digital transformation of the water systems and the application of graph network theory in drinking water distribution systems.

title: Professor
name: Guy Brown
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Machine learning, Speech recognition
short_biography: Professor Brown has led a team focused on the design and development of machine hearing systems at Sheffield for more than 25 years. From 2015-2023 he was Head of the Department of Computer Science. He is the co-editor (with DeLiang Wang) of Computational auditory scene analysis: Principles, Algorithms, and Applications (IEEE Press/Wiley-Interscience).
research_interest_summary: My main research interest is machine hearing, which aims to build AI systems that replicate the ability of human listeners to understand complex mixtures of sound. I have published on noise-robust automatic speech recognition, models of auditory function in normal and impaired hearing, models of binaural sound localisation and the phonetics of overlapping speech. Most recently my interests have focused on applications of machine hearing in health technology, particularly on the use of acoustic biomarkers to screen for sleep disordered breathing (obstructive sleep apnoea) and tuberculosis.

title: Professor
name: Haiping Lu
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Science, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Multi-agent reasoning, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: I am a Professor of Machine Learning, the Turing Network Development Award Lead, and Insigneo Research Director for Healthcare Data / AI at University of Sheffield. I am is also the lead organiser of the Alan Turing Institute’s interest group on meta-learning for multimodal data and the Machine Learning Theme Lead for Sheffield in the N8 Centre of Excellence in Computationally Intensive Research. I serve as an Associate Editor of IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, and IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems. I was a recipient of an Amazon Research Award, an AAAI Outstanding PC Member Award, and an IEEE CIS Outstanding PhD Dissertation Award. I am a Senior Member of IEEE.
research_interest_summary: My research focuses on developing translational AI technologies for better analysing multimodal data in healthcare and beyond, particularly multidimensional data and heterogeneous graphs in bioinformatics and medical imaging. I lead the development of the PyKale library (https://github.com/pykale/pykale) to provide more accessible machine learning from multiple sources for interdisciplinary research, officially part of the PyTorch ecosystem (https://pytorch.org/ecosystem/).

title: Professor
name: Hamish Cunningham
research_areas: Data-centric Engineering, Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Computer systems and architectures, Information retrieval, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Robotics, Speech recognition
short_biography: I used to hope that as time passed I would become older and wiser, but it seems that I just become odder and wider. Find me at https://hamish.gate.ac.uk
research_interest_summary: Dynamic conversation management for privacy preserving AI

title: Miss
name: Haolin Wang
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography:
Haolin is an AI Research Engineer (AIRE) at the University of Sheffield, under the lead of Prof. Haiping Lu.

Haolin received her Master’s degree in Data Analytics from the University of Sheffield in 2022. Prior to that, she received her Bachelor’s degree in Mathematics from the University of Oxford in 2021. See her LinkedIn for more information.

title: Professor
name: Helen Kennedy
research_interest_terms: Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Social media, Visualisation
short_biography: I am interested in how AI, automation and datafication are experienced by non-expert folk as part of their everyday lives, and strategies for living with data. This means thinking about how data, AI and automation come into being, the contexts in which they are made and shaped, how and whether they can be fair, equitable and just, how they should be governed, what good digital societies looks like and why the concept of ‘the digital good’ is so contested.
research_interest_summary:
In addition to the above,:
Current research: ESRC Digital Good Network (https://digitalgood.net/)
Recent research: the Living With Data programme (https://livingwithdata.org/)
I am also interested in data visualisaton in society, social media, platform politics and algorithmic culture. I have secured over £8m in research funding. Most of my research involves collaborating with non-academic stakeholders to seek to enact change (eg government departments, media organisations). 

I am on the strategy group for Responsible AI (RAI) UK: https://www.rai.ac.uk/.

title: Professor
name: Ian Kellar
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Humanities and Social Sciences
research_interest_terms: Information retrieval, Natural language processing, Social data science
short_biography: I am a professor of health psychology with expertise in developing and evaluating interventions that use behaviour change techniques for implementation both in the UK and in LMICs. I have been an investigator on research grants totalling £28.6 million of funding, of which 17 were peer-reviewed Research Council grants, including 5 NIHR Programme Grants for Applied Research and 2 NIHR Research and Innovation for Global Health Transformation grants.
research_interest_summary: I'm interested in the potential of automation to scale the analysis of qualitative data using behavioural science theories for use in large trials in behavioural medicine, and in the potential of ontology informed topic modelling to identify or extend behavioural science ontologies.

title: Dr
name: Iñaki Esnaola
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Information theory, Machine learning, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: Iñaki Esnaola is a Senior Lecturer (Associate Professor) at the Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering at the University of Sheffield, UK, and a Visiting Research Collaborator in the Department of Electrical Engineering at Princeton University, NJ, USA. He obtained a combined BSc and MSc in Telecommunication Engineering from University of Navarra, Spain, in 2006 and the PhD in Electrical Engineering from University of Delaware, DE, USA, in 2011. In 2010-2011 he was a Research Intern at Bell Laboratories, Alcatel-Lucent, Holmdel, NJ, USA, and in 2011-2013 he was a Postdoctoral Research Associate at Princeton University.
research_interest_summary: His research lies at the broad interface of information theory, communication theory, and high-dimensional statistics with an emphasis on the application to cyber-physical systems. More specifically, he studies the fundamental limits governing robust data acquisition and state estimation for systems operating with incomplete or mismatched model descriptions.

title: Dr
name: Jacob Macdonald
position: Lecturer in GIS and Spatial Analysis
affiliation: Department of Urban Studies and Planning
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Machine learning, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: Jacob Macdonald is Lecturer in GIS and Spatial Analysis with the Dept. of Urban Studies and Planning. He completed his PhD in Economics and Finance at the Nova School of Business and Economics, and then worked as a Geographic Data Scientist with the University of Liverpool and the Geographic Data Science Lab/ Consumer Data Research Centre. His teaching and research combines applied data science, urban and environmental spatial analysis for policy and planning.
research_interest_summary: My work makes use of the increasingly available big, spatial and open datasets for research in city sciences and planning. I have a broad interest in the economic and environmental spatial processes at play in the urban context, and how they influence our observed behaviour. My work has a common theme of using data and statistical methods to explore how individuals measure, value and interact with their local built and natural environments.

title: Dr
name: Jefersson A. dos Santos
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Science, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: Jefersson A. dos Santos is currently an Assistant Professor (Lecturer) in Computer Vision at the University of Sheffield, United Kingdom. He used to hold a position as Associate Professor at the Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais, Brazil (2013 - 2022). Jefersson is an IEEE Senior Member. He is currently an Associate Editor for the IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters and Co-Chair for the ISPRS Working Group for AI/ML for Geospatial Data. Jefersson also serves as a PC member for several refereed journals and conferences. Jefersson held the prestigious CNPq Productivity Research Scholarship (2016 - 2022).
research_interest_summary:
Jefersson research interests include machine learning, computer vision, image processing, and remote sensing. Besides always aiming at excellence and impacting outcomes in Computer Science, I am especially interested in inter-, cross-, multidisciplinary research.

His work in recent years has focused on developing new computational approaches and techniques to mitigate the problems of pixel-level image annotation for real-world applications, which especially include medical and remote sensing image analysis.

title: Mr
name: Jiabang Chen
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: Mr. Jiabang Chen obtained his Bachelor Degree from East China University of Science and Technology, and was an exchange student in the University of Sheffield from 2019-2020. In Sheffield, he worked with Prof. George Panoutsos for cancer cell image classification. He obtained his Master Degree from Imperial College London from 2020-2021, and worked with Dr. Kalofonou Melpomeni on primer design and cancer detection
research_interest_summary: My research interests mainly lie in deep learning, computer vision, medical image analysis, and explainable AI

title: Dr
name: Jiahong Chen
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics
short_biography: Dr Jiahong Chen is a Lecturer in Law at the University of Sheffield. Previously he worked at the University of Nottingham as a Research Fellow in IT Law, and before that, completed his PhD at the University of Edinburgh. He is the PI of the ongoing ESRC-funded project "The Internet of Tactical Engagement (IoTE)" (ES/Y00020X/1), addressing public attitudes towards data-driven public communications in smart homes and the associated policy implications. He is also a Co-I on the £4.38m Responsible AI UK Keystone project "Addressing Socio-technical Limitations of Large Language Models for Medical and Social Computing (AdSoLve)" (EP/Y009800/1), leading the legal use case to tackle the challenges around ChatGPT-like Generative AI systems.
research_interest_summary: His research focuses on the intersection between law and technology, in particular data protection law, cybersecurity law, law and AI, data ethics and internet regulation.

title: Dr
name: Jingxia Wang
research_areas: Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Social data science, Visualisation
short_biography: I am a researcher with expertise in spatial planning, land resources management, and urban nature, specializing in landscape and urban ecology, green infrastructure planning, and social-ecological systems research. Leveraging GeoAI and AI/ML methods, I apply advanced techniques for image analysis and spatial analysis to address urban challenges within the conceptual contexts of nature-based solutions, ecosystem services, climate change adaptation, and biodiversity conservation. Furthermore, I lead the AI-Interest Group, dedicated to addressing climate/environmental change and understanding biology through innovative AI approaches.
research_interest_summary: My current research involves integrating GIS, remote sensing, and AI techniques for image analysis and spatial analytics. I'm particularly interested in utilising environmental data from sensors, digital twins and IoT devices to inform decision-making in urban nature management. I explore the application of AI in analysing environmental and soundscape data and enhancing biodiversity connectivity.

title: Dr
name: Joanna Tidy
research_areas: Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Safety and ethics
short_biography: I am a Lecturer in the Department of Politics and International Relations, where I was previously Anniversary Research Fellow. Prior to that I held positions in the School of Sociology, Politics, and International Studies and the University of Bristol where my gained a Doctorate in Politics. I also hold an MSc in Social Science Research Methods, an Msc in International Relations, and a LLB in Law.
research_interest_summary: My interest in AI is grounded in my research on war and military violence, particularly in the context of gendered, raced, and colonial relations. I have a longstanding interest in the political, social, and cultural interface between military violence and technology. I am a Co-Investigator on the UKRI funded project Droned Life and part of the core team of the Centre for Drones and Culture (part of the Centre for the Future of Intelligence at the University of Cambridge). I am Principal Investigator on a AHRC/BRAID project scoping the responsible use of AI in the museum and heritage setting, specifically as this pertains to the use of collections of colonial origin as the underlying data for AI processes.

title: Dr
name: Joe Atkinson
research_areas: Humanities and Social Sciences, Security and Business and Public Policy
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics
research_interest_summary: Law and Regulation of AI

title: Dr
name: Joe Heffer
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Parallel computing, Visualisation
short_biography:
I work in the Research & Innovation IT team within IT Services as a Senior Research Data Engineer. We work in collaboration with researchers to implement data pipelines and other analytics solutions for their research projects.

We also provide consultations to give advice on data analysis tools and training courses for a range of digital research skills.
research_interest_summary:
- Automatic data processing workflows
- Efficient processes of large data sets
- Data standards and metadata generation

title: Dr
name: Jon Stammers
position: Senior Theme Lead - Data, Connectivity & AI
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Machine learning, Safety and ethics, Social data science
short_biography: Dr Jon Stammers is the Senior Theme Lead for Data, Connectivity and AI within the AMRC's Integrated Manufacturing Group. Based in the state-of-the-art Factory 2050, Jon's team has capabilities spanning Smart Factories, Data Security, Industrial IoT, Data Science, AI, and Computer Vision. He started his career at the AMRC working in and eventually leading the Process Monitoring and Control team, focusing on data capture from sensors and machine tools and deriving insight from the data streams. He sits on the IET's Manufacturing Technical Network committee, contributing to and organising events focused on digital manufacturing, and has co-authored a book chapter on Smart Manufacturing.
research_interest_summary: My research interests include the application of data science techniques within a manufacturing context, such as to identify significant performance indicators in large data sets, correlation of data sources from across the shop floor, and optimising data visualisation for its intended purpose. I am also very interested in how we can better prepare industry to adopt data-centric methods and AI.

title: Dr
name: Jonathan Aitken
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Computer systems and architectures, Computer vision, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Robotics, Safety and ethics
short_biography:
Dr Aitken holds a MEng (2005) and PhD (2009) in Electronic Engineering, from the University of York. He moved to the University of Sheffield in 2013 as a Research Fellow, before becoming a University Teacher in 2018 and a Senior University Teacher in 2021.

Dr Aitken previously worked in the Computer Science Department at the University of York, where he was a member of the High Integrity Systems Engineering Group, working on safety in Systems-of-Systems, especially dynamic risk assessment, and developed interests in evolving justifiably safe systems.
research_interest_summary: Dr Aitken is an experienced project leader, and has held 11 research council or industrial grants as either Principal or Co-Investigator. Currently he is a Co-Investigator of the EPSRC Platform Grant “Pervasive Sensing for Buried Pipes”. He is involved with the mapping and navigation systems for robots deployed in sewerage and clean water systems. This includes supervising projects developing novel AI-based simultaneous localisation and mapping algorithms, such as HFNet-SLAM.

title: Dr
name: Kate Miltner
research_interest_terms: Safety and ethics, Social media
short_biography: I am a Lecturer (Assistant Professor) in Data, AI, and Society at the Information School at the University of Sheffield and a Member of the UK Young Academy. Previously, I was a Marie Skłodowska-Curie Actions Fellow at The University of Edinburgh. I have held research appointments at Microsoft Research New England and Twitter, and visiting positions at the University of California, Berkeley and the University of Amsterdam. My research has been has been cited by the United Nations, the Council of Europe, European Parliament, the Nordic Council, the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe, the Law Commission, and the Department of Culture, Media, and Sport. In 2024, I was a finalist for the BBC New Generation Thinkers scheme.
research_interest_summary: I am interested in how (and in what forms) power circulates through digital ecosystems, how structural inequalities are (re)produced within and across digital contexts, and how power and inequality shape what happens—and for whom—in digital spaces. I am currently examining how portrayals of visual generative AI in advertising and news media have consequences for how we understand what generative AI is and who it is for. As a Co-I on the UKRI-funded Framing Responsible AI Implementation and Management project, I am investigating the key factors that influence how responsible AI is implemented and managed in both public and private sector institutions.

title: Dr
name: Kathryn Simpson
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Information theory, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Visualisation
short_biography:
I am a Lecturer in Digital Humanities in the Digital Humanities Institute (DHI), with a particular research focus on critical digital cultural heritage.
    I was previously a Lecturer in Information Studies at the University of Glasgow and prior to that a Fellow of the Institute for Advanced Studies in the Humanities at the University of Edinburgh.
    I am a Trustee of the David Livingstone Birthplace, Chair of both the Expert Advisory Panel and of the Audience, Learning, Engagement and Collections Committee. I am an Associate Project Scholar and UK Outreach Coordinator of Livingstone Online.
research_interest_summary: I am interested in digital tools and platforms which support open-access historical research and enable cross-silo scrapping of texts, images and objects to allow us to renegotiate histories in ways which do not belittle or obfuscate traditional knowledges and frameworks whilst providing richer and deeper understanding of heritage. I am particularly interested in the application of AI in cultural heritage environments and its use in negating or challenging established patterns and behaviours around museal collections.

title: Mr
name: Killian Gleeson
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Data structures and algorithms, Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Machine learning, Optimisation, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: Currently pursuing a PhD at the University of Sheffield, sponsored by Siemens UK. The aim of this PhD is to develop data analysis routines to derive actionable information from high-resolution water quality sensor data (aka smart water quality) within drinking water distribution systems. After obtaining an MSc in Environmental and Energy Engineering from the University of Sheffield in 2015, worked for 4 years as a data analyst in the test engineering industry for Nprime Ltd in Sheffield, assisting international manufacturing and defence companies to gain insights into the performance of their machinery and vehicles.
research_interest_summary: I am interested in using digitalisation to address real world engineering challenges, particularly in how we can optimise use of sensing technology to understand complex systems.

title: Professor
name: Laurence Brooks
research_interest_terms: Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Social media
short_biography: I am the Professor for Information Systems in the iSchool at the University of Sheffield. Previously, I was the Professor of Technology and Social Responsibility in the Centre for Computing and Social Responsibility (CCSR) at De Montfort University (DMU), where I still hold a visiting Professor role. At DMU I was the School lead for all PGT programmes, Programme Leader (PL) for MSc Information Systems Management (ISM), co-ordinated the PGT Dissertations, Past-chair of the Faculty Research Ethics Committee (FREC), PI on the H2020 funded TechEthos project, Co-Investigator on the H2020 funded SHERPA project, PI and co-ordinator of DMU's contribution to the EPSRC funded Horizon: Creating Our Lives in Data, Centre for Doctoral Training (CDT).
research_interest_summary: My current interests focus on the ethical and responsible aspects of AI. This has been reflected in the UKRI funded FRAIM project, looking at Framing Responsible AI Implementation and Management (https://sites.google.com/sheffield.ac.uk/fraim/home). The key issues are how we should be using AI, as opposed to how we can, to make the world a better place, while not making things worse.

title: Mr
name: Lawrence Schobs
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Science
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: I am a third year PhD student researching medical image analysis with deep learning. I focus on landmark localization and estimating uncertainty.
research_interest_summary: computer vision, medical image analysis, landmark localization, segmentation, uncertainty estimation

title: Professor
name: Li Su
research_interest_terms: Neuroscience and cognitive science
short_biography: Professor Li Su is Chair of Neuroimaging and the Head of the Artificial Intelligence and Computational Neuroscience Group. He has a joint appointment at the Neuroscience Institute, University of Sheffield and the Department of Psychiatry, University of Cambridge. His research group and laboratory locate in both universities. He is a Fellow at Clare Hall, University of Cambridge and a Specialist Committee Member at National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE). He is a regional co-lead for the National Network for the Application of Data Science and AI to Dementia Research (DEMON) and member of Grant Review Committee for the Lewy Body Society.
research_interest_summary: He leads the Artificial Intelligence & Computational Neuroscience Group, which aims to combine innovative and original computational methods with the state-of-the-art brain imaging techniques such as MEG/EEG, 7T MRI and PET in understanding, detecting and developing treatments for neurological and psychiatric conditions.

title: Professor
name: Lyudmila Mihaylova
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Computer vision, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Multi-agent reasoning, Robotics, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: I am a Professor in Signal Processing and Control at the Automatic Control and Systems Engineering Department, on Sheffield Robotics and Insigneo. I serve as Associate Editor-in-Chief for the IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems, a Senior Area Editor of the Signal Processing journal and as part of the organising committees of IEEE conferences on information fusion, ICASSP, conferences on intelligent transport and others.
research_interest_summary: I have broad research interests and expertise in the areas of autonomous systems with applications to cities, autonomous and assisted living systems. My recent work is in the areas of machine learning, intelligent sensing, navigation, tracking and other tasks with multi-sensor data – from images and videos to time series data. Autonomous image and video analytics faces a number of challenges due to the huge volumes of data that sensors provide, the changeable environmental conditions and other factors. However, it is important to know when the methods work well and when they are not reliable, e.g. how much could we trust the obtained results? How could we quantify the impact of uncertainties on the developed solutions?

title: Dr
name: Madhu Pahar
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Speech recognition

title: Dr
name: Madhurananda Pahar
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Speech recognition
short_biography: Madhu is an energetic, motivated, hardworking, enthusiastic, experienced ML and AI engineer & researcher, working to apply machine learning and signal processing in the field of Biology. He studied Mathematics in hin undergraduation and focused on applied mathematics in his MSc. His PhD was devoted towards developing a biologically inspired audio coding technique.
research_interest_summary:
Madhu is working to apply machine learning and signal processing in the field of Biology.
Previously, he was involved in detecting and classifying TB and COVID-19 vocal audio, such as cough, breath and speech in real-world environments, as well as monitoring patients' long-term recovery using smart sensors, such as an accelerometer, in South Africa.
He also developed deep learning methods from third-generation sequencing (Oxford Nanopore) signals to study genomics, epigenomics, transcriptomics and epi-transcriptomics in the USA. Currently, he is analysing speech to automatically detect the signs of early cognitive decline,​ such as mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and dementia, in Sheffield, UK.

title: Dr
name: Mahnaz Arvaneh
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Machine learning, Neuroscience and cognitive science
short_biography: Dr Arvaneh is a Senior Lecturer at the Department of Automatic Control and Systems Engineering, University of Sheffield. Her research focuses on user-centred design of non-invasive closed-loop neural interfaces and their applications in monitoring and enhancing physical and cognitive performance. She is the director of Brain-Computer Interface laboratory, where she conducts theoretical, experimental as well as translational research to develop therapeutic neuro-technologies. Her work on neural interfaces has received international recognition and high-profile media coverage, e.g. BBC Tech Tent, BBC Radio 4, Sky News. She contributed to the “Royal Society expert perspective report on neural interface technologies” launched in 2019.
research_interest_summary: My primary research interests are in the areas of brain-computer interface (BCI), neural signal processing, machine learning and their applications in monitoring and enhancing physical and mental health. I am the director of Physiological Signals and Systems laboratory at University of Sheffield, where we combine analytical and experimental techniques to develop improved therapeutic, assistive, adaptive and rehabilitative technologies for a variety of conditions.

title: Dr
name: Mark Dunning
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: I obtained my PhD in the Statistics and Computational Biology group of Simon Tavare at The University of Cambridge. As part of my thesis I developed open-source software for the analysis of Illumina microarray data. I joined the Bioinformatics Core at Cancer Research Uk Cambridge Institute and played a key role in the analysis of gene expression profiles as part of the METABRIC project, which identified and described new subtypes of breast cancer. During my time in the Bioinformatics Core I also developed a passion for teaching and commenced a role dedicated to organising and delivering Bioinformatics training courses, with the aim of upskilling wet-lab scientists and foster more-productive collaborations with Bioinformaticians.
research_interest_summary: I run the Bioinformatics support facility at the University of Sheffield. The remit of our group is to provide analysis support and training for researchers conducting high-throughput biological studies,. As these datasets become more complex and varied there is a increasing potential to apply AI to address challenges in healthcare and disease. Please get in touch and see how we can support your work.

title: Dr
name: Mark Hodgkinson
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Parallel computing
short_biography: I have extensive experience analysing large datasets and writing data processing algorithms for High Energy Physics Experiments. I did my Phd with the University of Manchester, spending most of the time on placement at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Laboratory working on the BaBar experiment.  I then joined the University of Sheffield as an e-science software developer for several years working on data processing software for the ATLAS experiment at CERN. I was subsequently a Research Associate working on the ATLAS experiment with Sheffield before being promoted to Research Fellow.
research_interest_summary: As the main developer of the Particle Flow data processing algorithm, used by the ATLAS experiment to process data centrally for physicists to subsequently analyse, I am particularly interested in how we could augment or replace this with a machine learning approach. Currently I am interested in studying Convolutional Neural Networks, Graph Neural Networks and Mixed Density Networks to provide predictions of charge particle energy deposits in the ATLAS particle detectors. I have in the past worked on usage of machine learning techniques to identify particle types on High Energy Physics Experiments, some of which are currently deployed as standard techniques used in the ATLAS data processing workflows.

title: Dr
name: Mark Stevenson
position: Senior Lecturer in Natural Language Processing
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Information theory, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Optimisation, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Visualisation
short_biography: I am a Senior Lecturer in Computer Science and member of the Natural Language Processing group. I have been Principal Investigator of projects funded by a range of sources including the EPSRC, EU and Google. I have been an EPSRC Advanced Research Fellow and previously co-ordinated an EU-funded project. Before taking up my current role I worked in a range of commercial and academic organisations including Reuters Ltd (where I was involved in the production and dissemination of the widely used Reuters Corpus), Adastral Park (British Telecom’s research lab) and the Center for the Study of Language and Information, Stanford University.
research_interest_summary: My research focuses on Natural Language Processing and Information Retrieval. My main interest is in the development of systems that allow users to access information contained within large collections of documents and to make decisions based on this information. To this end I have worked on a range of topics including lexical semantics, scholarly document processing, Information Extraction, plagiarism/reuse detection, Technology Assisted Review, exploratory search and evidence synthesis. I have applied these technologies to a range of areas including biomedical text mining, cultural heritage and software testing.

title: Dr
name: Max Champneys
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Data structures and algorithms, Information retrieval, Information theory, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Optimisation, Parallel computing, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: Max is a research fellow in AI for sustainability and resilience as part of the centre for machine intelligence at the university of Sheffield, a post he has held since November 2024. He was awarded his PhD in nonlinear structural dynamics at the University of Sheffield in March 2023. Max has also held a number of postdoctoral positions looking at the treatment of uncertainty in structural dynamics.
research_interest_summary: Max has a general interest in the treatment of uncertainty in engineering and beyond. Max's research centres around data and AI driven quantification and propagation of uncertainty in complex interdisciplinary systems with applications from populations of offshore wind turbines to characterisation of ultra-thin materials with neutron reflectometry.

title: Mr
name: Max Gamill
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: I am a PhD student in the Materials Science and Engineering department at the University of Sheffield working within the Pyne lab, led by Dr Alice Pyne. I graduated from the University of Leeds, obtaining a First Class master’s degree in Physics, where I implemented and analysed the quality of deep learning 3D super-resolution models under the supervision of Dr Aleks Ponjavic. Here, I also completed a year in industry with IBM as a technical support analyst for the business reporting tool Cognos Analytics.
research_interest_summary:
The flexibility of DNA allows it to adopt a wide range of conformations induced by its compaction within the nucleus, and interactions with DNA-processing enzymes during vital cell processes such as transcription and replication. This variation in topological complexity has been shown to influence DNA-protein interactions such as those with Topoisomerases, antibacterial and anti-cancer therapeutics and CRISPR-Cas-9.

My research investigates DNA topological complexity seen in atomic force microscopy (AFM) images, and aims to quantify features and characteristics seen within datasets via machine learning techniques in an open and accessible way through our AFM image processing software, TopoStats (https://github.com/AFM-SPM/TopoStats.git).

title: Dr
name: Michael Farnsworth
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Computer vision, Human computer interface, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Optimisation, Robotics
short_biography: Dr Farnsworth graduated from the biological sciences having pursued a BSc in Biochemistry at Cardiff University before undertaking an MSc in Computer Science at the University of the West of England. He continued with his interest in biologically inspired computation, undertaking a PhD at Cranfield University on the evolutionary design optimisation of Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS). He continued with this theme over a number of projects throughout his time at Cranfield University and the University of Sheffield, ranging from autonomous maintenance, manufacturing informatics and process optimisation. He is currently the lead researcher for the digital manufacturing theme within the EPSRC Future Electrical Machines Manufacturing hub.
research_interest_summary: In my current role as a research associate within ACSE and research lead within the FEMM hub I focus on developing digital and sensor-based solutions for automation and tracking and traceability of manufacturing processes. The core of this research is centred on my interests in biologically inspired computing, whether it be evolutionary computation, machine learning and AI, or robotics and cognitive neuroscience. This includes investigating the latest deep neural network-based machine vision and machine learning solutions, whilst exploring novel bio-inspired event based sensors and cognitive architectures. In my free time I also explore how machine learning can be incorporated into the field of climate science and modelling.

title: Professor
name: Mike Thelwall
research_interest_terms: Natural language processing, Social data science, Social media
short_biography: I am a social scientist, programmer and mathematician. have researched social media methods and bibliometrics (research evaluation), collaborated on many international multidisciplinary research projects and have worked on external contracts applying innovative bibliometrics for various external organisations, including the United Nations Development Programme. I was part of the Metric Tide group that evaluated the role of bibliometrics in the Research Excellence Framework and now sit on the UK Forum for Responsible Research Metrics. In 2022 I led a team assessing whether artificial intelligence could play a role in future research assessment in the UK.
research_interest_summary: I am interested in applying machine learning to social science problems. I have used machine learning for sentiment analysis and research quality estimation but am looking to connect to other social scientists to work on applied problems.

title: Dr
name: Min Tao
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Science, Humanities and Social Sciences, Security and Business and Public Policy, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Computer systems and architectures, Data structures and algorithms, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Multi-agent reasoning, Optimisation, Parallel computing, Robotics, Statistical methods and theory

title: Mr
name: Mohammod Naimul Islam Suvon
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning, Natural language processing
short_biography: Mohammod Suvon completed his bachelor's degree in Computer Science and Engineering from North South University, Dhaka, Bangladesh. He has recently completed his Master's in Computer Science with speech and language processing at the University of Sheffield, UK. Currently, he is working as a research support engineer under Dr. Haiping Lu.
research_interest_summary: Mohammod Suvon's current research interest is in multimodal learning on clinical datasets.

title: Dr
name: Monica Lestari Paramita
research_areas: Data-centric Engineering, Humanities and Social Sciences
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Natural language processing, Social data science
short_biography: I am a Lecturer in Data Science and the deputy head of the Information Retrieval Research Group in the Information School, University of Sheffield. I obtained my PhD from the Information School, University of Sheffield in 2019. Prior to my lectureship, I worked as a researcher for 10 years in diverse areas of Information Retrieval and Natural Language Processing. My research roles included investigating cross-lingual similarity in the Web, developing systems to support information access, and analysing users' behaviour when interacting with such systems. I have co-authored over 25 publications, ranging from conference papers, book chapters, and journal articles.
research_interest_summary: My research focuses on the study of bias and transparency in information retrieval and multilingual information access. I am especially interested to investigate how bias-aware search engines should be designed to support users in their search tasks. I am also interested in researching cross-lingual similarity in Wikipedia; this includes creating methods to measure cross-lingual similarity, understanding the extent of dissimilarity in Wikipedia and why they exist, and how this impacts different users (e.g., users in different locations or those speaking different languages).

title: Ms
name: Nabila Cruz
affiliation: Department of Sociological Studies, University of Sheffield
research_areas: Humanities and Social Sciences, Security and Business and Public Policy, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Safety and ethics, Social data science
short_biography: Nabila is a PhD student with over eighteen years’ experience as an information professional. She studied Politics and International Studies at the University of Warwick and, after gaining a master’s degree in Information Science at UCL, she worked at various information and research management roles in libraries and universities in London. She joined the Department of Sociological Studies in 2022 to pursue a doctoral research opportunity investigating the interrelationship between trust and inequalities in the context of digital media. Her project is part of Designing For All, a BBC Research and Development programme aiming to address the challenge of digital inequality and inclusion through responsible innovation.
research_interest_summary: Nabila’s PhD project investigates how AI-generated media may affect young audiences trust in the news. She will be interviewing industry practitioners and young adults to gather their perceptions and uses of AI, which will help in setting up creative workshops using generative AI. She is also currently working as a student research associate in the Creative Library Project at the University of Sheffield Library, exploring explore creativity and knowledge justice which the aim of liberating the library.

title: Dr
name: Neda Azarmehr
position: Lecturer in Data Science and AI
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: Neda joined the Information School in January 2025 as a Lecturer in Data Science and AI. She holds a PhD in Computer Science with a focus in computer vision for cardiovascular imaging, particularly echocardiography, from the University of Lincoln (2021) in collaboration with Imperial College London. After completing her PhD, she worked as a Postdoctoral Research Fellow at the University of Sheffield School of Dentistry, where she developed advanced deep learning algorithms for CR-UK funded projects using digital pathology images. Prior to this, she was a Lecturer in Computer Science and the Course Director of the MSc AI program at the University of West London. She is a Fellow of the HEA and a Royal Academy of Engineering Frontiers awardee.
research_interest_summary: Neda’s research focuses on deep learning and computer vision techniques in healthcare domains, particularly medical imaging and computer-aided diagnosis. Examples of Neda’s research include automated echocardiography view detection with a focus on lightweight deep neural network, left ventricle segmentation, speckle tracking in echocardiography, colonic polyp detection, and the quantification of digital pathology images with a focus on head and neck cancer. Neda is also interested in trustworthy AI, focusing on issues such as bias, fairness, and interpretability in algorithm development and inference. She aims to explore multimodal AI and generative models for future integration in medical imaging.

title: Mr
name: Neil Ireson
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Machine learning, Natural language processing
research_interest_summary: My research interests can broadly be defined as knowledge acquisition from data. This has primarily focused on the use of Machine Learning, most recently applied to the understanding of individual and population movements: to identify mobility patterns indicative of criminal activity, such as drug and human trafficking; and using mobile device sensor data to understand how contextual factors (e.g., weather, journey purpose) influence mobility, for health and well-being.

title: Dr
name: Nemanja Vaci
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Natural language processing
short_biography: I am psychologist and applied statistician with extensive experience in data science.
research_interest_summary: I am interested in how people develop their knowledge and skill over a lifetime. My research focuses on the investigation of how we learn and develop expertise when we reach the peak level of performance, and how we experience age-related decline in performance. As well as factors that relate to cognitive decline in the case of age-related diseases, such as dementia. I use large and passively collected data: chess, NBA, and football records in expertise research and electronic health records (EHRs) in clinical research.

title: Dr
name: Olayiwola Oladiran
research_areas: Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Machine learning, Robotics, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: Ola is currently a Lecturer in Real Estate at the Urban Studies and Planning Department. He gained his PhD in Real Estate and Urban Economics from Henley Business School, University of Reading. He previously worked as a Lecturer in Real Estate at Leeds Beckett University and Henley Business School, University of Reading. His research focuses on real estate economics with a core interest in digital/IT applications to real estate (PropTech), residential real estate, and operational real estate markets.
