research_interest_summary: My broad research interest is in real estate economics. I am currently exploring the various ways through which digital technology can enhance the efficiency of real estate operations and practice, and how these can further improve various aspects of the built environment. I also utilise various quantitative techniques to understand the demand and pricing mechanism in operational and residential real estate markets.

title: Mr
name: Peizhen Bai
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Science
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Information theory, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Parallel computing
short_biography: I am a CS Ph.D. student at the University of Sheffield, supervised by Dr. Haiping Lu. My research focuses on domain transferability challenge arising from machine learning (esp. graph-based methods) adoption in real-world drug discovery. Previously, I worked at Apple Siri team as a data engineer, developing large-scale machine learned system. I am contributing to the development of open source PyKale Library and Sheffield AI Turing Network.
research_interest_summary: Deep Representation Learning, Graph Neural Networks and Knowledge Graph in Drug Discovery.

title: Professor
name: Peter Bath
position: Professor of Health Informatics and Data Analytics
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Humanities and Social Sciences
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Privacy and trust, Social data science
short_biography: Peter Bath has been undertaking research applying statistical methods and AI methods to analysing health data for over 25 years. His interests are in identifying predictors of health and well-being in older people, but he is also interested in other groups. He has authored almost 300 publications including 136 articles in refereed journals in print and 115 refereed conference proceedings/abstracts. Recently Peter has been working with colleagues in scHARR to identify predictors of adverse outcomes among people with suspected COVID-19 during the pandemic. Peter has supervised over 30 PhD students to successful completion. Other areas of research interest include health information behaviours and evaluating health information systems.
research_interest_summary: Peter is currently working on the Pre-Hospital PRIEST study, which is developing tools to predict adverse outcomes among people with suspected COVID-19. This has involved the use of statistical methods and AI methods to develop better predictive models. Peter is also examining outcomes among older people through secondary analyses of the English Longitudinal Study of Ageing (ELSA). Other work has involved examining the utility of patient-level data for population health management for the former Rotherham Clinical Commissioning Group (RCCG). Peter is the Training and Capacity Building lead for the HDR-UK Northern Care Homes Partnership.

title: Dr
name: Prasun Chandra Tripathi
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: Prasun Chandra Tripathi received B.Tech. degree from Uttar Pradesh Technical University, Lucknow, and M.Tech. degree from University of Hyderabad, Hyderabad. He did Ph.D. degree from Indian Institute of Technology (ISM), Dhanbad, India. Currently, he is working as a Postdoc Research Associate with Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield.
research_interest_summary: My area of interests lies in medical image analysis, deep learning, and image processing.

title: Dr
name: Preeti Raghunath
position: Lecturer in Digital Media and Society
research_areas: Humanities and Social Sciences, Security and Business and Public Policy, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Information theory
short_biography: Preeti Raghunath is a Lecturer in Digital Media and Society at the Department of Sociological Studies, University of Sheffield. Preeti’s current research is on the histories and presents of the global data economy. She is studying colonial histories and contemporary aspects of datafication and infrastructures in India, exploring questions of equity and sustainability. She is involved in an action research project on community data governance in Sri Lanka with colleagues at Monash University, Australia. Preeti is keen to develop her research in digital technologies and patient-centricity in neurohealth (myelopathy). She maintains an active interest in critical and southern approaches to AI, data and its governance.
research_interest_summary: Southern Approaches to AI

title: Mr
name: Rea Nkhumise
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Computer vision, Information theory, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Multi-agent reasoning, Robotics
short_biography: I'm a robotics engineer with entrepreneurial experience, and have affinity for tackling complex problems with practical application to the general masses - hence I founded a startup company in Robotics & Software. I appreciate the interdisciplinary and system thinking approaches in applying robotics research to mitigate commonly faced societal problems.
research_interest_summary: My work is about Robotic Reinforcement Learning which aims to enable industrial robotic manipulators reach complete autonomy, through self-learning of new tasks and adapting to perturbations fast and flexibly.

title: Professor
name: Richard Clayton
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Parallel computing, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: My undergraduate degree was in Applied Physics, followed by a PhD in Medical Physics based at the Freeman Hospital in Newcastle upon Tyne. I continued in research funded by British Heart Foundation fellowships, before moving to Sheffield Computer Science in 2003.
research_interest_summary: My research interests range from physiological signal processing through to multiscale modelling of the heart. More recently I have focussed on statistical machine learning methods for uncertainty quantification and model calibration.

title: Dr
name: Rob Snell
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Data structures and algorithms, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Optimisation
short_biography:
I work on all aspects of additive manufacturing (AM; 3D Printing). I work on a variety of materials (polymers, ceramics, moon dust, etc.) and a variety of technologies (electron beam, direct energy deposition, etc.) but the majority of my work is with metals on laser powder bed fusion.

I also work on alloy design and component design, with a particular interest in space, nano-satellites and AM-produced optics.
research_interest_summary:
AM is a gradual process of forming weld tracks into layers, and layers into parts, so that every voxel can be monitored and analysed. There are challenges with this:-
1 - The best data comes from high-frame rate cameras with a small pixel size. This though means TB of data per layer. It is necessary to filter, process and store this data quickly.
2 – Ensuring the data has a physical relevance. A pyrometer value is meaningless if it doesn’t help us. Working out what sensor values are “good” and what are likely to cause defects is not trivial.
3 – Solving things in a cost effective manner. Many attempts to solve the AM data issues involve expensive sensors and simple trial parts. Solutions need to be scalable.

title: Dr
name: Robert Loftin
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Human computer interface, Machine learning, Multi-agent reasoning, Natural language processing, Robotics
short_biography: Robert received his PhD in Computer Science from North Carolina State University in 2019, under the supervision of Dave Roberts.  After completing his PhD, he did a two-year post-doc with Microsoft Research Cambridge, exploring the use of Reinforcement Learning and Interactive Learning in commercial game development. He also completed a post-doc at TU Delft with Frans Oliehoek, where he focused on applying game theory and multi-agent reinforcement learning to human-AI cooperation.  Robert is currently a Lecturer in Machine Learning at the University of Sheffield.
research_interest_summary: My research focuses on how AI can learn through interaction with humans. Virtually all applications of AI involve solving problems defined by humans. The goal of my work is to allow humans and artificial agents to work together to build a shared understanding of such tasks, enabling AI that leverages human knowledge, and ensuring that learned behaviors are truly aligned with human intentions. My research attempts to cover all aspects of this problem, from its theoretical foundations to the development of scalable interactive learning algorithms, and their evaluation with real human users. My work spans many topics within and related to AI, including (Deep) Reinforcement Learning, Game Theory and Multi-Agent Systems, and Cognitive Science.

title: Dr
name: Robert Turner
research_interest_terms: Machine learning
short_biography: Bob is a senior research software engineer who started his career in software and databases after completing a degree in Applied Physics at the University of Durham. After four years in the private sector, he did a PhD in Biophysics at the University of Leeds, before working as a postdoc researcher at the University of Sheffield in several departments, including Physics and Astronomy, Molecular Biology and Biotechnology Mechanical Engineering and the Dental School, reflecting an unusually broad range of research interests spanning microscopy, microbiology, engineering and healthcare.
research_interest_summary:
Bob’s role includes contributing to the management of the RSE team, under Paul Richmond’s leadership. His work includes:

- Advising and helping researchers to implement good software engineering practises (e.g. testing, version control, documentation, reproducible execution, packaging, licensing)
- Writing research software (e.g. in Python, MATLAB, R)
- Training
- Establishing new externally-funded collaborations
- Advocating and acting to improve the standards of research software (e.g. running or delivering talks, communication via social media, engagement with university committees)

title: Dr
name: Rodrigo Kazu Siqueira
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Machine learning, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Visualisation
short_biography:
ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3511-6439
Scopus Author ID: 56590059200 

I am a researcher in computational neuroscience with experience in complex networks, comparative neuroanatomy and cell culturing. I am a member of INSIGNEO and a data scientist for the AMRC at the University of Sheffield. My primary computational skills include Python, C/C++, MATLAB, R, data mining, predictive analysis and data analytics All of that with the communication of actionable results demonstrated by my various talks and papers, most of which are available online.
research_interest_summary: My research interests include general intelligence, network neuroscience and information processing in the somatosensory cortex.  My latest work helped people walk again through the modelling of tactile responses for real-time feedback prosthetics! Additionally, I am trying to change the way we understand brain development utilising a computational model of neuronal networks based on brain evolution network neuroscience. Currently at the AMRC, I am shaping the next generation of data scientists leading a project called NextGen that also showcases the capabilities of our AMRC data cloud. I am also a part of several projects that include data analytics, technical delivery and client engagement for data-driven projects in manufacturing.

title: Professor
name: Roger K. Moore
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Human computer interface, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Robotics, Speech recognition
short_biography: Prof. Moore has over 40 years’ experience in Speech Technology R&D and, although an engineer by training, much of his research has been based on insights from human behaviour.  As Head of the UK Government's Speech Research Unit from 1985 to 1999, he was responsible for the development of the Aurix range of speech technology products and the subsequent formation of 20/20 Speech Ltd.  Since 2004 he has been Professor of Spoken Language Processing at the University of Sheffield, and also holds Visiting Chairs at Bristol Robotics Laboratory and University College London Psychology & Language Sciences.  He has been President of the International Speech Communication Association, and is current Editor-in-Chief of Computer Speech & Language.
research_interest_summary: spoken language processing by mind and machine; vocal interactivity between 'intelligent' agents; embodied and situated communicative behaviour

title: Dr
name: Ronald Dyer
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Humanities and Social Sciences
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Information retrieval, Machine learning, Robotics, Visualisation
short_biography:
I possesses over 20 years of project management experience across financial service, education, agriculture and energy focused organisational transformation initiatives.

He has worked on several large IT integration projects at Goldman Sachs, Citi-Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank.

Dr. Dyer is a graduate of Grenoble Ecole de Management, France, where he attained a Doctorate in Business Administration, holds an MBA in Project Management from - Henley Graduate School of Business University of Reading, UK as well as undergraduate degree from Wilfrid Laurier University, Canada in Business Administration.
research_interest_summary:
Research focuses on utilization of game-based-learning, data visualization and artificial intelligence - technology assets (i.e. artefacts) for improved decision-making and problem-solving within organization. The research is underpinned by ludus and paidia theory, presenting opportunities for innovative co-created solutions informing human performance improvement through game-play.

These tech-assets/artefacts incorporate AI and analytics leveraging play typologies to identify user approaches to adoption and optimization of operational capabilities, improved synthesis of information, contextualization of opportunities, problems-analysis, scenario development and organizational performance.

title: Dr
name: Ross Drummond
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Optimisation, Robotics
short_biography: I am research fellow in ACSE and will join as a lecturer upon the completion of my fellowship in Dec '23. Before then, I was a post-doc in the Control Group at the University of Oxford.
research_interest_summary: My research interests focus on the use of control theory and its application to modelling and management of batteries. I have developed tools that use the techniques from control theory to compute robustness certificates. I have used these techniques to provide stability guarantees, robust pruning methods and to connect neural networks to model predictive control.

title: Dr
name: Saleh Farazi
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Humanities and Social Sciences, Security and Business and Public Policy, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Human computer interface, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Social media
short_biography: Dr. Mohammad Saleh Farazi is a Lecturer (Assistant Professor) in Strategy at Sheffield University Management School. He has also taught Technology & Innovation Management at New Jersey Institute of Technology, Carlos III University of Madrid, Sharif University of Technology, and Rotterdam School of Management (Erasmus University). His work has appeared in globally acclaimed journals such as Research Policy, R&D Management, and Technovation, among others, in addition to being presented at major international conferences. He regularly reviews for several leading Management journals and he also sits on the Editorial Board of the South Asian Journal of Business Studies.
research_interest_summary: Saleh is an applied researcher with a passion about the strategic management of technological innovation and a particular focus on the healthcare sector. He is interested in studying how digital health platforms can create more value for the society and how they are transforming the economy. He is also interested in exploring the strategic management of knowledge and technology in R&D partnerships, including biopharma alliances. As a secondary research interest, he has also taken part in collaborative research that seeks to identify the origins of the gender gap in financing social ventures (i.e. why is it that female social entrepreneurs are less likely to raise equity financing, and what can be done to bridge the gap?).

title: Dr
name: Samer Alabed
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Data structures and algorithms, Information retrieval, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Visualisation
short_biography: I am a Clinical Lecturer in Radiology at the University of Sheffield and senior Radiology Registrar at Sheffield Teaching Hospitals. In my 11 years of NHS experience, my clinical interest centres on cardiac imaging, particularly the assessment of ischaemic heart disease with stress perfusion cardiac MR and coronary CT. I completed an advanced cardiac imaging fellowship at the Royal Papworth Hospital and attained high-level cardiac MR and CT accreditation and serve as the co-Chair of the Trainee Committee for the British Society of Cardiovascular Imaging.
research_interest_summary:
My research centers on advancing and evaluating machine learning applications within the realm of cardiac imaging. This encompasses automated diagnosis, anatomical segmentation, and prognostic assessment. Currently, my work merges deep learning image analysis with report generation to streamline cardiac MRI assessments.

I hold the positions of Topol Digital Fellow and DAAD AI-Net Fellow. I am an active member of the AI working group at the Royal College of Radiologists and have received The Parliamentary Future of NHS Award and the Medipex NHS Innovation Award.

title: Dr
name: Samuel Birks
research_interest_terms: Knowledge representation, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics
short_biography: Dr Samuel Birks is a University Teacher in Medical Education within the School of Medicine at the University of Sheffield. He is clinically trained by background and practises as a doctor in the Emergency Department whilst also working as an educator in the medical school. His role in academia encompasses digital learning and he has led the development of guidance on the use of generative AI in undergraduate and postgraduate medical education.
research_interest_summary: Dr Birks' research and professional interests include generative AI literacy amongst students and academic staff, the use of generative AI as a tool for learning, and the ethical and academic considerations of incorporation of AI into education.

title: Dr
name: Saori Shibata
research_interest_terms: Automatic control, Data structures and algorithms, Human computer interface, Information theory, Machine learning, Optimisation, Privacy and trust, Robotics, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Social media, Speech recognition, Visualisation
short_biography: Saori Shibata is a lecturer at the University of Sheffield. Her research focuses on Japan’s political economy, including the changing nature of work, the digital economy and how Japan’s model of capitalism is transforming. This draws on institutionalist approaches to capitalism and critical political economy. She has published on these topics in journals such as New Political Economy, Review of International Political Economy and British Journal of Political Science. She is the author of Contesting Precarity in Japan: The Rise of Nonregular Workers and the New Policy Dissensus published by Cornell University Press.
research_interest_summary: My research focuses on Japan’s political economy, including the changing nature of work, the digital economy and how Japan’s model of capitalism is transforming. My most recent seeks to identify the conditions under which digitalization can maximise the autonomy of users and producers and minimise the experience of coercion and surveillance. It addresses the dilemma whereby digitalisation has the potential to both improve the scope for autonomous engagement, and at the same time has the potential to erode autonomy through mechanisms of surveillance and control, seeking to understand under what conditions digitalisation advances or impedes autonomy. This draws on institutionalist approaches to capitalism and critical political economy.

title: Mr
name: Scott Herod

research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Visualisation
short_biography: Technical Lead for AI and Modelling at the University of Sheffield AMRC's Design and Prototyping Group (DPG).

I am interested in many forms of AI and machine learning such as, machine vision and image analysis techniques, Reinforcement Learning, Natural Language Processing, Large Language Models, Classical machine learning techniques, mathematical modelling and simulation.

I also have a background in VR/AR work and visualisation.

title: Dr
name: Shaoxiong Sun
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering
research_interest_terms: Machine learning
short_biography:
Dr. Shaoxiong Sun is a Lecturer in Pervasive Data Science at the Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield. Previously, he was a Senior Research Associate in Data Science in Mobile Health at King’s College London. He was awarded a PhD from a joint program between Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands and Philips Research, focused on physiological monitoring. 
 
Dr. Sun has over 30 peer-reviewed publications and 2 patents granted through the PCT system. He served on the technical program committees for IEEE CHASE 2022 and IEEE BSN 2023. He is also a guest editor for Frontiers in Signal Processing, Frontiers in Digital Health, and Algorithms.
research_interest_summary: Dr. Sun's research interests primarily revolve around physiological and behavioural monitoring, leveraging advanced signal processing and machine learning methodologies. In the realm of physiological monitoring, he focuses on estimating vital parameters such as blood pressure, heart rate, and respiration rate through the analysis of biomedical signals, such as photoplethysmography (PPG). In behavioural monitoring, his work centres on assessing mobility and social interaction patterns using wearable devices and smartphones. Dr. Sun has developed innovative technologies aimed at assisting individuals with a range of medical conditions, including depression, multiple sclerosis, epilepsy, ADHD, and COVID-19.

title: Miss
name: Sheeba Ancy Koilpillai
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Security and Business and Public Policy
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Knowledge representation, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Visualisation
short_biography: Data Manager for Data Connect and South Yorkshire Digital Health Hub
research_interest_summary: As a Data Manager, I manage and curate sensitive patient-level health datasets, ensuring compliance with NHS ethics, GDPR, and data governance standards. I oversee database management and pseudonymization, preventing re-identification while maintaining data integrity and security. My role involves implementing access controls, auditing data processes, and ensuring adherence to NHS Data Security and Protection (DSP) standards. I apply the Five Safes framework for responsible data access and the FAIR principles to enable ethical data sharing and interoperability. Collaborating with researchers, ethics committees, and data custodians, I support privacy-preserving research while protecting participant rights.

I am an academic fellow in machine learning at the Machine Learning Research Group, Department of Computer Science, University of Sheffield.

My current research focuses on developing interpretable machine learning methods and tools for medical image analysis. I am a co-creator and core developer of open-source library PyKale, which provides a range of accessible multi-modal and transfer learning algorithms.

I serve as a reviewer of IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems and IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems. I also served as a PC member of IJCAI 2022. I am an awardee of Post-Doctoral Enrichment Awards (PDEA) 2022, offered by the Alan Turing Institute.

title: Mr
name: Sina Tabakhi
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Science
research_interest_terms: Data structures and algorithms, Information retrieval, Information theory, Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: I am a PhD student in the Department of Computer Science at the University of Sheffield, under the supervision of Professor Haiping Lu. I am also an organiser of the Alan Turing Institute’s interest group on Meta-learning for multimodal data. I am a contributor to the development of Sheffield Data Science and AI Network with the support of the Turing Network Development Award. I serve as a reviewer of IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, Pattern Recognition, and Neural Computing and Applications.
research_interest_summary:
My research focuses on advancing the field of healthcare diagnostics through integrating multimodal health data and developing an accurate diagnostic system for life-threatening diseases. I use graph neural networks to comprehensively analyse progressive diseases, particularly in multiomics data, to identify key biomarkers associated with specific disease conditions.

Furthermore, my research tackles large-scale healthcare data challenges through multi-agent systems for joint feature selection. This approach captures intra-omics and cross-omics interactions and reduces the dimensionality of data while preserving crucial information. This enhances computational efficiency and model interpretability, facilitating better healthcare decision-making.

title: Dr
name: Sophie Whittle
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: I am a Research Associate in Digital Humanities at the University of Sheffield (DHI), with an interest in digital medieval studies, pedagogical and AI edition-making, (historical) syntax and corpus linguistics. I completed my PhD in historical linguistics at the School of English in 2023, where I was also a Graduate Teaching Assistant and became Fellow of the Higher Education Academy.
research_interest_summary: I am currently working on the C21 Editions project in the DHI, where I am responsible for producing a prototype digital edition of Geoffrey Chaucer's Canterbury Tales. I work with insights from learning and teaching communities to design a digital scholarly edition which utilises machine-assisted/AI methods. I am also interested in the political, sociocultural and ethical issues involved in the use of GenAI in the classroom and other pedagogical environments. In particular, I am interested in the level of scholarly and editorial intervention required when using AI methods to interpret queer theory in the Middle Ages, and more broadly, the disruptive nature of medieval/cultural texts.

title: Dr

short_biography:
I investigate AI, data and evidence, and how they work for and against the publics they ostensibly serve. 
This means investigating data and analytics and how they work in policy and practice contexts and the ethics of their role in social change.
I am interested in the processes of datification, digitialisation and automation as they experienced, by those from across society that promote their use, in policy, workplaces and our everyday lives, and those who are concerned, resist or simply ignore them.

title: Dr
name: Tamora James
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Science, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: Tamora began her career in web and software development, later completing an MRes and PhD in population ecology and conservation demography at the University of Sheffield. During her PhD she became interested in how she could help other researchers to improve their research software outputs by teaching them about commonly used software development tools and practices. After completing her PhD, she joined the Centre for Environmental Modelling and Computation (CEMAC) at the University of Leeds where she worked on projects including weather forecasting in Africa, visualisation of climate co-benefits, and detection of biometeors in radar data. In 2023 she returned to the University of Sheffield as a Research Software Engineer for AI/ML.
research_interest_summary: Tamora’s role involves providing research software engineering support for AI/ML projects, including CMI-funded RSE support for members of the University community to enable, design, implement and refine AI/ML applications in their research projects.

title: Dr
name: Thomas Wilkes
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Information retrieval, Machine learning
short_biography:
Thomas joined The University of Sheffield in 2015, where he completed a PhD on the development of low-cost remote sensing instruments for application in volcano monitoring. Subsequently, as a post-doctoral researcher at The University of Sheffield, he was responsible for the development and wider dissemination of SO2 measurement systems.

In 2021 he began a three-year Leverhulme Early Career Fellowship at Sheffield. The project aims to improve our understanding of SO2 emissions from volcanoes, namely their measurement, associated errors, and how these relate to volcanic activity.
research_interest_summary: I began my academic career as a geoscientist but through my PhD (and beyond) I have developed further skills and interests in software engineering (predominantly in Python), instrument design and machine learning. I have recently developed a CNN model for the semantic segmentation of explosive volcanic plumes in webcam imagery, with the aim of automating the provision of important monitoring parameters for volcano observatories. As machine learning continues to grow rapidly, and become more freely/easily available to end-users, I continue to look for ways that it can be used to help to solve problems in volcanology.

title: Dr
name: Tom Pering
research_interest_terms: Machine learning, Mathematical modelling, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: I am a volcanologist and Senior Lecturer at the University of Sheffield with an interest in developing low-cost monitoring techniques with the goal of eruption forecasting. I am also interested in understanding the mechanisms for eruptive activity in basaltic magmas. I obtained my PhD in Volcanology from the University of Sheffield following on from a Masters in Volcanology and Geological Hazards at Lancaster. My teaching in the department includes first and second year statistics.
research_interest_summary: The volcano team at Sheffield has a particular expertise in the usage of ultraviolet cameras for the measurement of sulphur dioxide emissions. We are currently developing the techniques and protocols for full and automated usage of these systems, looking to incorporate machine learning techniques. I am also interested in the modelling of gas-liquid flow computationally and in the lab.

research_interest_summary: I am interested in the psychology of learning, decision making and reasoning, and how these may be studied using data intensive methods  and methods from computer science

title: Dr
name: Venet Osmani
position: Senior Lecturer in Data Science for Health
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Data structures and algorithms, Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Multi-agent reasoning, Natural language processing, Neuroscience and cognitive science, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Social data science, Statistical methods and theory, Visualisation
short_biography: Before joining the University of Sheffield, I was a tenured Senior Researcher in Digital Health Centre at Fondazione Bruno Kessler research institute, Italy where I led a group of researchers and students in tackling challenges in medicine using machine learning methods. I was also a lecturer in the department of Psychology and Cognitive Science at University of Trento, Italy.
research_interest_summary:
My research interests are in developing machine learning methods, to address some of the fundamental questions in medicine. These include:

    predictive modelling
    explainable AI
    generative adversarial approaches (GAN)
    causal inference
    health inequality and bias

My work focuses on analysis of large-scale, longitudinal health records, including:

    biomarkers
    imaging
    multi-omics
    routine health care data

The main aims are to optimise treatment strategies, improve patient care, and provide novel insights to health institutions.

title: Dr
name: Vincent Obia
research_interest_terms: Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics
short_biography: Vincent is a Leverhulme Early Career Fellow researching AI and new media regulation in Africa
research_interest_summary: Vincent's research interests include AI governance, data policy, and the design, use, and regulation of new media technologies between the Global North and South

title: Mr
name: William Deakin
research_interest_terms: Computer systems and architectures, Computer vision, Data structures and algorithms, Human computer interface, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Natural language processing, Optimisation, Privacy and trust, Safety and ethics, Visualisation
short_biography: Following post-graduate studies in solid-state physics at the University of Manchester, my  background is in applied application artificial intelligence in published and electronic media. Following working in system delivery in the European mobile telephony I currently work in the British Rail industry as the technical assurance and delivery lead for national systems and interfaces for timetable and strategic planning, operations and performance systems.
research_interest_summary: My professional interests are in an assessment of the state of the art in information and meaning extraction from unstructured text and documents. I also have an interest in visual data representation for safe methods of work, data visualization and effect network transport flow algorithms for constrained systems. For example, plan and constraint optimization in the European rail network.

title: Dr
name: Xi Wang
research_areas: Data-centric Engineering, Science, Humanities and Social Sciences
research_interest_terms: Information retrieval, Natural language processing
short_biography: Xi Wang is currently a lecturer of Natural Language Processing at the University of Sheffield, working on the research topics of conversational AI, personalisation as well as other relevant topics among natural language processing and information retrieval. Before joining Sheffield Uni, he was a postdoctoral researcher at UCL with a research focus on task-oriented dialogue systems. Moreover, he received his PhD from the University of Glasgow under the supervision of Prof. Iadh Ounis and Prof. Craig Macdonald from the Terrier team.
research_interest_summary: My research interests are mainly in conversational AI and personalisation. However, I also extensively collaborated with researchers on extended research topics related to natural language processing and information retrieval.

title: Dr
name: Xianyuan Liu
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning
short_biography: I currently serve as a Senior AI Research Engineer at the Department of Computer Science, and as the Assistant Head of AI Research Engineering at the Centre for Machine Intelligence, both at the University of Sheffield. My current research focuses on developing machine learning methods and tools for healthcare and multi-modal learning.
research_interest_summary: Domain Adaptation

title: Dr
name: Xin Zhao
research_interest_terms: Information theory, Knowledge representation, Statistical methods and theory
short_biography: I am a University Teacher at the Information School and a Senior Fellow of HEA. I hold a PhD in Education from the University of Bath. I am an IG lead for the AI for Education interest group.
research_interest_summary: My research delves into the social implications of artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, emphasizing crucial aspects such as AI literacy, accessibility, equality, and the pressing need for comprehensive training to ensure its effective and ethical use.

title: Mr
name: Ze Zhang
research_interest_terms: Computer vision, Machine learning, Robotics
short_biography:
Ze Zhang is currently a Research Associate within the Department of Automatic Control and
Systems Engineering at the University of Sheffield, and a research theme lead within the EPSRC Made Smarter Innovation - Research Centre for Connected Factories on the topic of in-process monitoring. He finished his Ph.D. in 2023 at the University of Sheffield on deep learning based sensor fusion and received his M.Sc. degree in Electronic and Electrical Engineering from the University of Sheffield in 2018. Before his research career, he worked in the electric power industry after graduating from his B.Sc at Jiangnan University in 2012.
research_interest_summary: His research focuses on the use of artificial intelligence for manufacturing systems, including in-process monitoring and robot perception systems. His interested technologies include sensor fusion, multi-modal fusion, computer vision and generative deep learning.

title: Dr
name: Zheng Yuan
position: Senior Lecturer in Natural Language Processing
research_areas: Health and Medical Sciences, Data-centric Engineering, Humanities and Social Sciences, Cross-cutting Challenges
research_interest_terms: Human computer interface, Information retrieval, Knowledge representation, Machine learning, Multi-agent reasoning, Natural language processing, Social data science, Social media
short_biography: Zheng Yuan is a Senior Lecturer (Associate Professor) in Natural Language Processing (NLP) in the School of Computer Science at the University of Sheffield. Before joining Sheffield, Zheng was a Lecturer in the Department of Informatics at King's College London, a Research Associate in the Department of Computer Science and Technology at the University of Cambridge, and a Fellow in Computer Science at Trinity College (Cambridge). Zheng holds a PhD in Natural Language Processing and an MPhil in Advanced Computer Science from the University of Cambridge, as well as a BSc(Eng) from Queen Mary University of London.
research_interest_summary: Zheng is working on machine learning for natural language processing, including real-world applications in education, creativity, healthcare, social media, and finance.
